sect1.title: Boot and Installation Media
sect1.para: When installing the system, the media for booting and for installing the system may be different. All combinations of supported media for booting and installing may be used.

sect2.title: Boot Media
sect2.para: Booting a computer depends on the capabilities of the hardware used and the availability of media for the respective boot option.

listitem.para: This is the most common possibility of booting a system. It is straightforward for most computer users, but requires a lot of interaction for every installation process.

varlistentry.term: Booting from a USB Hard Disk

listitem.para: Depending on the hardware used, it is possible to boot from a USB hard disk. The respective media must be created as described in .

You can only boot a computer directly from the network if this is supported by the computer's firmware or BIOS. This booting method requires a boot server that provides the needed boot images over the network. The exact protocol depends on your hardware. Commonly you need several services, such as TFTP and DHCP or PXE boot. If you need a boot server, also read .

sect2.title: Installation Media
sect2.para: The installation media contain all the necessary packages and meta information that is necessary to install a openSUSESUSE Linux Enterprise ServerSUSE Linux Enterprise DesktopSUSE Linux Enterprise Real Time Extension. These must be available to the installation system after booting for installation. Several possibilities for providing the installation media to the system are available with openSUSESUSE Linux Enterprise ServerSUSE Linux Enterprise DesktopSUSE Linux Enterprise Real Time Extension.

listitem.para: All necessary data is delivered on the boot media. Depending on the selected installation, a network connection or add-on media may be necessary.

If you plan to install several systems, providing the installation media over the network makes things a lot easier. It is possible to install from many common protocols, such as NFS, HTTP, FTP, or SMB. For more information on how to run such an installation, refer to .
